Award.AwardTitle: Low-complexity Stochastic Modeling and Control of Turbulent Shear Flows

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Most flows in nature and in engineering applications are complex and disordered (turbulent). Dissipation of kinetic energy by turbulent flow around airplanes, ships, and submarines increases resistance to their motion (drag); about half of the fuel required to maintain the aircraft at cruise conditions is used to overcome the drag force imposed by the turbulent flow. Similarly, in wind farms, turbulence reduces the aerodynamic efficiency of the blades, thereby decreasing the energy capture. Understanding and controlling turbulent fluid flows plays an important role in these applications, and may critically impact US economy, national security, and the environment. The broader impacts of this award range from economic and environmental benefits to improved performance of wind farms, transporting pipes, and vehicles. The Principle Investigators (PIs) plan to organize a workshop on modeling and control of fluids at the Institute for Mathematics and its Applications. This workshop will be aimed at showcasing utility of control engineering and systems theory to an interdisciplinary audience of students, researchers, and professionals from the engineering, mathematics, and physics communities.

The intellectual merit of this project's effort lies in the novelty and interdisciplinary nature of the research. Second-order statistics of turbulent flows can be obtained either experimentally or via numerical simulations. The statistics are relevant in understanding fundamentals of flow physics and for the development of low-complexity models. Such models will be used for control design in order to suppress turbulence. Due to experimental or numerical limitations it is often the case that only certain spatio-temporal correlations between a limited numbers of flow field components are available. Thus, it is of interest to complete the statistical signature of the flow field in a way that is consistent with the known dynamics. The approach to this inverse problem relies on a model governed by stochastically forced linearized Navier-Stokes equations. Here, the statistics of forcing are unknown and sought to explain the given correlations. Identifying suitable stochastic forcing will allow the PIs to complete the correlation data of the velocity field. While the system dynamics impose a linear constraint on the admissible correlations, such an inverse problem admits many solutions for the forcing correlations. The PIs will use nuclear norm minimization to obtain correlation structures of low complexity. This complexity translates into dimensionality of spatio-temporal filters that will be used to generate the identified forcing statistics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Fluid flow modeling and control is an interdisciplinary research area in which the tools from modern optimization and control theory are opening new grounds for the understanding of fundamental flow physics, data-driven refinement of physics-based models, and model-based flow control. The ability to manipulate and control fluid flows is critically important in many applications including the design of fuel-efficient and environmentally-friendly autonomous air and water vehicles and mixing enhancement in chemical reactors, heat exchangers, and combustion engines. The potential benefits of successful flow control strategies are enormous; they range from economic gains in energy savings to improved performance of engineering systems involving fluid flows. One of the major challenges in estimation and control of fluids is the development of low-complexity models that are in agreement with statistical signatures of turbulent flows. Because of experimental or numerical limitations only correlations between a limited number of flow field components are available in high-speed flows. Thus, it is of interest to complete the statistical signature of the flow field in a way that is consistent with the known dynamics and convenient for optimization and real-time control. 

To address this challenge, this NSF Award developed a new paradigm for explaining statistics of systems with large number of degrees of freedom using models of low complexity. Although, in turbulent flows, the Navier-Stokes (NS) equations capture all features of the underlying dynamics they are prohibitively complex for analysis, optimization, and model-based control. Instead, the developed approach relies on a model governed by stochastically-forced linearized NS equations. Here, the dynamical generator is known, and it is obtained by linearizing the nonlinear flow equations around the turbulent mean velocity profile. On the other hand, statistics of forcing are unknown and are sought to explain the available velocity correlations. This NSF award showed that white-in-time stochastic forcing is not sufficient to explain turbulent flow statistics and the available data was used to refine predictive power of first-principle models. More specifically, the tools and ideas from systems theory and convex optimization were combined to merge data-driven with physics-based modeling and develop low-complexity models for colored-in-time stochastic forcing. 

The utility of the developed tools was demonstrated in turbulence modeling. For the first time, it was showed that partially-available second-order statistics of turbulent channel flows can be exactly reproduced and that unavailable entries of covariance matrices can be completed by shaping the power spectral density of stochastic forcing to the linearized flow equations. This fundamental result addresses several long standing challenges in merging data-driven with physics-based modeling; it also introduces a new class of structured matrix completion problems, where the underlying structure comes from the requirement that statistics are generated by the linearized NS equations. It further demonstrates tremendous richness of the linearized turbulent flow dynamics and it provides a critical step towards the development of data-driven refinements of turbulence models. This paves the way for the design of more efficient and environmentally-friendly fluid flow systems, including air and water vehicles.
